timeline.bodyText: If we seek backward should sequential count always be set to 0?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: yeah i was undecided about this one, but probably rare to see someone jump forward and then jump back in the stream?
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: Should this only be incremented if bytesRead > 0?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: Is it guaranteed that in is positioned correctly?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: good catch, fixed
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: Do these numbers require tuning or is the heuristic good enough?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: We could further tune these, but experimentally journal replays are as fast as before, will verify remote spark tpcds behavior soon.
replies.author: yuzhu

replies.bodyText: nit: add a comment describing these as counts and not a bytes limit
replies.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: if they require tuning, i prefer and property. we can choose to make it hidden in case we don't want to add to the user's confusion.
replies.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText:
So I am actually leaning towards making these not tunable for now. A tunable parameter is only useful if there is some metric / log message that suggests these parameters need to be tuned. Right now we don't have any of that. These default values should work well out of the box.
How about we add a TODO here to make another PR with the appropriate diagnostic metrics and make it tunable in that PR?
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: We still need to skip in the stream if we are in the sequential read mode and n is less than the movement limit?
timeline.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: it is not necessary, because our mPos is the ground truth. As long as we maintain mPos, we can delay any seek or skip until when we actually read.
replies.author: yuzhu

replies.bodyText: In that case, a read pattern like read, read, read, skip(1), read, skip(1), read will cause us to lose the sequential read mode at the last read. Is this intended?
replies.author: calvinjia

replies.bodyText: yes, fixed. it became obvious once i started writing the test.
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: nit: this seems to be a clone of FilterInputStream javadoc. I don't think we need a copy here.
timeline.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: nit: this doesn't need to be a nested class? separate file for readability
timeline.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: nit: comment why pread is never called
timeline.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: nit: comment that skip > MOVEMENT_LIMIT causes pread. maybe even mark MOVEMENT_LIMIT @VisibleForTesting and re-use 2*MOVEMENT_LIMIT to avoid changing the test if we tune the parameter.
timeline.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: nit: comment that read > SEQUENTIAL_READ_LIMIT causes . similar to above consider exposing SEQUENTIAL_READ_LIMIT for testing and using a for loop here to avoid changing the test after possible tuning
timeline.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: nit: the comment above is mis-placed?
timeline.author: madanadit

timeline.bodyText: nit: also this comment seems mis-placed as this method makes no decision about pread api
timeline.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: nit: in this test can we also check if the data read back is what we expect, in addition to the API used to read?
timeline.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: is this seek necessary or guaranteed to be a no-op if say I have 10 continuous reads as we reset mSequentialReadCount and seek after every 3 reads?
timeline.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: I changed this part a bit so we don't do the noop seek. Basically we do the seek lazily if we are in sequential mode, and don't reset the counter until we seek or skip a large step.
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: see above, i now avoid this seek entirely by doing it lazily in the read.
replies.author: yuzhu

timeline.bodyText: nit: for readability i prefer a method called  isSequentialReadMode to determine whether to seek or not
timeline.author: madanadit

replies.bodyText: done
replies.author: yuzhu
